column1: Box 1. Estimating Fiscal Multipliers in Qatar and the GCC (concluded)  1 This box summarizes key findings of the Selected Issues Paper “Estimating Fiscal Multiplier for Qatar.” 2  These interpretations are suggestive, as the model does not control for other potential determinants and the rolling approach further reduces the sample size.

column2: Box 1. Figure 1. Growth Impact of Central Government Capital Spending 1/ (12-year rolling coefficient and one standard deviation plus or minus the estimate) Capital Spending, First LagCapital Spending, Second Lag0.60.60.40.40.20.200-0.2-0.2-0.4-0.4950005101520950005101520End year of rolling sample End year of rolling sample   Sources: Haver and IMF staff. 1/ Non-hydrocarbon output is regressed on current spending (L0 and L1), capital spending (L1 and L2), global output, and oil prices, all in real growth rates, on a 12-year rolling basis ending in the year indicated on the horizontal scale, using annual data for Qatar spanning 1983–2023. Coefficients on the first and second lag of capital spending are displayed.
